review_title: Great place to enter mortgage industry
job_title: Mortgage Loan Closer in Tampa, FL
pros: Benefits. Generous PTO and Sick Pay. Overtime. Good place to get your feet wet in the mortgage industry. Work from home during Covid.
cons:
They took away bonuses in First mortgage and that felt like a low blow. Our salaries are not that great according to industry standards and so that was a way to earn more income. This is my first mortgage job and I do not feel like I was well trained. My manager is always swamped and I do not feel like she is able to manage well because of the workload placed upon her. I do not feel like this is a long term career but a starting point. Changes are made without notice. We are expected to do other people's work if they are behind on their load and then we in turn get behind
 For a big company they need to be more in tune with the latest in the Mortgage industry and then cascade that down in a well planned training. Trainings feel like long rants without barely any pause. Overall BOA is a good company but First Mortgage needs serious work.  I also hate the fact that we dont know whether we will be going back to the office or not. I have elderly parents and I wont be able to return to the office for their safety and mine. The uncertainty adds unnecessary stress.

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Houston, TX
pros:
Benefits-
Health, Dental, Vision, paid time off, paid sick time, tuition reimbursement, inclement weather pay, matching 401k.

If you like constant sales goals and helping clients who may not understand the financial world it might work for you. You can move up in the industry but the sales goals increase with every promotion.
cons:
Stress-
Everyone I knew who worked here was constantly stressed out. You have to do more than your share of work most of the time. Long lines, out the door during peak days. Very little help, especially during the pandemic. I would do anywhere from 100-250 transactions per day. Had to verify every single transaction at the end of the day, count my teller box and that of the vault. Do all the reports and most of the closing and opening procedures. If we were short staffed I had to count other tellers boxes as well. The center I worked at had very challenging clients. We would receive threats and complaints on a semi daily basis. They installed over head cameras to look at everything you do. Which is fine, but it piles on the stress knowing they're watching every mistake you make from a remote location. On top of stress from the clients, the low staffing, you have to promote sales goals for the personal bankers. It pays well but it is very demanding.

pros:
Reasonable benefits including government holidays.
Stable company will probably be around a long while.
cons:
Office politics are very heavy here.
The money to be made is at the top echelons--most of the top execs are raking in large annual increases while most workers are getting a tiny percent (if anything). Even strong-performers get only small annual increases which are nearly the same as under-performers. Increases are usually less than inflation.
The work is less satisfying here because much time is spent on meeting the requirements of regulators and auditors rather than actually doing IT work.
Once in a position, if you do a good job in that position, it is virtually impossible to move to another position. Moving to a new position is very much top-down in this organization--the management decides what you should be doing and they will move you into that role with little or no input from you.
Of all the jobs I have worked, the stress level here is higher than anywhere else.

cons: This relates primarily to my perception of the culture, but in general everyone's experiences will probably have a lot of various. Most of the decision-making and information sharing occurs at the senior leadership level, so although there's lots of opportunities to learn and it's difficult for it to translate into a clear understanding of what to prioritize and how to make a meaningful contribution. job_title: Bank Teller in Crystal Lake, IL
pros: Amazing Medical Insurance Benefits Only
cons: They hire you for one location then after you’re hired they send you anywhere else they want on a moments notice. You can work for the company for almost a decade and they dispose of you like trash. You can ask managers and employee relations and HR for help and they don’t care. When you call voicing frustrations that the place you have been transferred to, unwillingly, is 2 hours round trip from home & the commute is causing unnecessary stress on you & your family, they tell you to see a therapist or a doctor to find out how to deal with it. Branch can have no toilet & they tell you you will have to drive across the street to go at the grocery store. Told management there was a strong smell of propane/gas in a back closed door room (that we used all day and had to keep the door closed while we were using it and the bank is open for business ), for a year and a half, only to find out later after something else needed fixing that there were not 1 but 2 gas leaks. Asked a manager one time if I could go pump as a nursing mother with a newborn at home & was told I had to wait quite some time (Even though there was plenty of staff coverage for me to use my required lunch break to do this), while I was in pain and about to leak through my shirt. Employees that were a known close contact & in the presence of another positive employee, are not required to submit a negative test upon return to the branch and only needed to take 2 -3 days off. At the beginning of the pandemic the bank allowed people who were “high risk” or had “high risk” family to stay at home getting paid for doing nothing, then were trained to work in the call center department from home, while the rest of us (including people with high risk family who didn’t know they could call and work from home), were torn from our home branches and forced to drive all over the place so far from home in branches so crowded with angry customers there was no way to socially distance anywhere. This was under the guise that we would be going back to our branch however now they’ve started closing them permanently and not working with the employees to find them a place closer to home or they shuffle people even further away without asking. We are forced to wear bank provided masks (that are not KN95 which are supposed to be the most effective). The bank slogan of “we’re better when we’re connected” is a sham. There has never been more disconnect between employees and management and employee relations than there is now. Given the current worldly events, this is extremely disheartening. This bank does not care about employees even the employees who have put in so many years of their life, dedication and talents and spent so many hours away from their families commuting to and fro. Beware.

review_title: A good retirement home, but definitely a trap for any ambitious person
pros:
- Impossible to get fired - if you're junior, just come to work & you will likely be employed the next year. Biggest risk is breaching compliance e.g. not completing your training on time (that is VERY serious). Managers just need to clap like seals when senior managers talk & they are set. If they can write fancy emails and cc mgmt that is even better. 

-Pay is good relative to the amount of effort you put in (close to zero)

-Good entertainment perks e.g. Dinner budgets
cons:
- Most managers won't teach you anything. Mgmt's KPI is how well they can delegate work to subordinates. Most have 0 idea about the business they are running, but rely on competent subordinates to do the job. Most subordinates will eventually leave, except those who are trapped on 500K salaries but contribute very little. 

-Bonus is one of the lowest on the street. Unless you're the CEO making 23 million dollars & taking a private jet from Charlotte to Boston every week. Don't expect to be paid well (esp in Equities) & your bonus is not very well correlated to your output (which is intentionally kept very vague). 

-Feels more like a charity than a bank that cares about profits. I understand the importance of diversity/inclusion, but it is done a bit excessively here. E.g. Internal seminars that teach you how to interact with LGBT.....

- The bank actively disencourages innovation. Obviously, they don't put it like this, but try to suggest new ideas & it will likely die in layers of bureaucracy after your request is forwarded through three different continents. Most technology applications & popular websites are blocked, and most tech teams will either not respond or come back to you weeks later. It helps to have a boss who has sway in the bank & can help you get resources, so if you don't.... then too bad. 

-Onboarding clients is a pain. The amount of documents required by the team is often painful for clients, and clients who want to do business with us are often turned away for random reasons such as 'Lacking potential'. These decisions are often made by people in the team who can't tell the difference between alpha & beta.

-Everyone good is gone. There was once a time when there were still good people in the division. I define good as people who know clients well & have a good sense of the market. Those have mostly gone either to the buyside or moved to other houses. This means that the people you are left with cannot teach you anything that will make you useful to clients. 

There are so many more but these are specific to this bank and specific to a division and specific to a region.

During non-pandemic times, at least within my team I always feel valued and look forward to the challenges that the day will bring me, and my performance never goes unrecognized.
cons: upwards movement or to other lines of business from consumer outside of consumer is sometimes prohibitively difficult. Leadership who does not come from banking background can sometimes feel unsupportive because they don't know how things work down at the ground level.

job_title: Small Business Consultant in Garden Grove, CA
pros: When the pandemic started, Bank of America really showed how much they cared about their employees and took care of us... Giving us great benefits and great relief options, not firing us, giving us the option of working from home without any pay decrease while providing work equipment for us. We still got our bonuses from what we got on average without having any goals... They wanted to make sure our income stayed the same and we wouldn't struggle during covid. I am super grateful to be working for this company, and now I see it very clearly since the pandemic started. When things go bad, people's true colors came out, and I am so happy to be apart of this company.
cons: Lots of politics involved, but that's with every company.

job_title: Wealth Management Banking Specialist in Dallas, TX
pros:
-Depends on the office you’re in, but I work with some awesome people
-Benefits: $1/$1 401k match up to 5%, good insurance, employee discounts on tons of stuff including loans and mortgages, $400/yr FSA contribution from the company, and lots of obscure benefits that you’d never think of
-4 weeks of vacation per year, even as a new employee 
-Great company culture. They really seem to care about their employees. I get this vibe from management all the way up the ladder
-Product knowledge required for job is easy to learn
-Excellent paternity/maternity leave, 16 weeks paid
-Growth potential is virtually unlimited
-Diverse possibility of locations to transfer to
-If you’re in a job that’s not a good fit, but you’re a competent and responsible employee, they’ll do everything they can to find a better position for you
cons:
-Compensation seems low for this kind of job. And it’s salary+bonus, but there’s no objective financial incentive to meet sales goals because the size of your bonus is at the discretion of your manager.
-It’s a big company, so things don’t change quickly when they need to
-Have been working from home with Covid, but no flexibility to do so if it weren’t for that
-Way too many conference calls and too much nannying, regardless of performance
